Allow to set proc for expireat

There is a trap in the `expireat` example in the in the README.

```ruby
value :value_with_expireat, :expireat => Time.now + 1.hour
```

`expireat` is evaluated at class load time.
In this example, it will be one hour after evaluating class,
not after one hour after setting value.

If you want to expire one hour after setting the value,
`expireat` can not be satisfied that use case.

So add expireat implementation with proc.

```ruby
value :value_with_expireat, :expireat => lambda { Time.now + 1.hour }
```

If can set proc, `expireat` will be used more flexibly.

For example, if want to expire at 0:00 am every day,
It can be written as follows.

```ruby
value :value_with_expireat, expireat: -> { 1.day.since.midnight }
```

This case can not be written in `expiration`.

Fixes case of hmget empty collection

When 
- fields is `nil`, `*fields.flatten` is `[nil]`:  hmget returns `nil`
- fields is `['no-such-key']`, `*fields.flatten` is `['no-such-key']`: hmget returns `nil`
- fields is `[]`, `*fields.flatten` is `[]`: hmget raises a `Redis::CommandError` as the array must not be empty

Fixed the problem with delete operations on lists.

The problem:

list = Redis::List.new(:marshal => true)
a = {:foo => 'bar'}
list << a
list.delete(a) # => does not delete a
list.delete(Marshal.dump(a))# => delete a

This problem is fixed, now you can do list.delet(a)
fix for copy/paste

Fix specs for redis-rb >= 2.0.7 del semantic change

$redis.del returns an integer rather than a boolean.  This is correct because it indicates the number of keys that were
successfully deleted
fix typo for SortedSet#delete_if
Hardcoded class names should be from the root level or we can get name collisions with Redis::Objects internals

Allow subclasses of classes implementing Redis::Objects to automatically pick up objects from their superclasses.

This is a two-pronged approach.  First, when we call one of the declarative class methods that defines the
accessors for the object, we hardcode the class reference for access @redis and @redis_objects.  The second
part is to update the field_key methods in the core Redis::Objects module so that they explicitly look up the
class to reference via first_ancestor_with.  This ensures that the key name is consistent with where the object
was declared.

Tests cover the base inheritance case where no further redis objects are declared (which should make it compatible
with ActiveRecord STI I'm hoping, but that's untested), as well as the case where an object is overriden by a
subclass, and a new object is declared.
Make rake test just run bacon with all the files so that you can see all errors instead of only errors in the first file that fails (there are many failures on redix 1.2.x)
